Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Stability and Dynamics of Tissue Cell Assemblies in Yield Stress Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Summary:

This CAREER award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Florida is to investigate biological systems from a perspective of condensed matter physics by employing the modern materials and tools of engineering and materials science. This award is cofunded by Biomechanics and Mechanobiology program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation(ENG/CMMI). To recruit and retain a diverse student population, the educational objectives of this proposal are to diminish stereotypical views of Mechanical Engineering discipline by systematically integrating soft matter topics into undergraduate curriculum and extra-curricular activities. Persistent exposure to interdisciplinary topics will be provided to all Mechanical Engineering majors throughout their undergraduate careers in the form of lectures, labs, career advising, and an extramural field courses in collaboration with a marine research laboratory. The proposed education and research activities are integrated; the materials in the proposed research will be used in teaching, and the education strategy is expected to grow the pool of potential students for research activities. The proposed education plan is to shift the demographic makeup of a large, traditionally homogeneous field. Education activities target underrepresented groups in STEM fields and proposes to increase their participation in STEM related research in academia and industry. The proposed research creates a new platform for 3D cell culture with potential social benefits; the development of a new effective cellular biomaterial may advance biomaterials research, biomedical research, biomedical technology, and medicine. The most likely potential impacts would occur in wound healing and tissue engineering technologies. In the treatment of acute wounds, for example, biocompatible yield stress materials could be ideal wound healing scaffolds. Analogous to 'bone putty', these materials can be extruded as a fluid to completely fill a topographically complex wound, and solidifying very quickly.

Technical Summary:

This CAREER award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Florida is to investigate biological systems from a perspective of condensed matter physics by employing the modern materials and tools of engineering and materials science. This award is cofunded by Biomechanics and Mechanobiology program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation(ENG/CMMI). The proposed research objective is to leverage the basic physics of instability, topology and symmetry to study tissue cell dynamics. Cell assemblies will be 3D printed by the direct extrusion of structures into volumes of yield stress material. Yield stress materials are solids when applied stress is low; and they are fluids when stress is high. The combination of cells and yield-stress materials provides unprecedented control of variables like size, shape, symmetry, and topology in multicellular structures. The main focus of this proposal is to study: (1) mechanical instabilities in simple structures to classify and measure collective cell forces; and 2) the role of symmetry and topology of complex multicellular structures in collective cell dynamics. The proposed investigation of the yield-stress cellular biomaterial is significant because it: (1) creates a superior platform for carrying out fundamental investigations of 3D cell dynamics; (2) creates a new class of biomaterial never before investigated; and (3) explores fundamental aspects of collective cell dynamics that previously could not be done due to limitations of available support materials. The proposed activities are founded on a new concept that breaks away from the established paradigm in cellular biomaterials, potentially advancing knowledge in the areas of basic tissue mechanics and physiology, tissue culture methodology, and cellular biomaterial science and engineering. The proposed educational efforts incorporate extensive data collection of the students' perspective of Mechanical Engineering, demographic attrition rates, and job placement. This data would provide new knowledge about the causes and remedies of the historical lack of diversity in student population enrolled in mechanical engineering courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The ultimate research-related outcome of the work performed in this project was new understanding of collective cell behavior in 3D structures. By creating a diversity of different structures made from cells and extracellular matrix, and by carefully measuring how these structures deform and disintegrate under the physical forces generated by the cells they contain, my group discovered an empirical scaling law that relates cell-generated stress to the elastic modulus of the cells? microenvironment. We found that this scaling-law applies to cells grown on 2D substrates and grown in 3D matrix. To arrive at this ultimate outcome, we made many scientific discoveries and technological developments, which contribute to several different areas of science and engineering. These discoveries and developments include:

1. We developed a new 3D printing method that enables fabricating structures from practically any Soft Matter material or complex fluid, without the need for specialized ?inks? or scaffolding. Our method leverages the dual solid-like and fluid-like behaviors of soft particles when densely packed. When a hollow needle is inserted into these packed ?microgels? and translated, the soft microparticles temporarily re-arrange and flow, then come to rest and lock back into place once external forces are removed. Practically any material can be extruded out of the hollow needle as it moves through the microgels, and once the needle leaves a location the microgels pack around the deposited material, supporting it in 3D space. By carefully measuring the thickness of individual features printed under different conditions, we discovered that a simple volume-conserving continuity equation was able to predict the feature-size from the nozzle translation speed and the material deposition rate, demonstrating a high level of control and predictability with this 3D printing method. This work had a major influence in the 3D printing field, and connected this field with those in soft matter physics studying jamming and glassy behavior in systems of soft particles.

2. We extended our 3D printing method to bioprinting and cell culture, developing a new material that serves simultaneously as a support material for 3D bioprinting and as a 3D culture medium.  By swelling microgels in liquid cell culture medium and formulating packed phases, then 3D printing structures made from cells or extracellular matrix (ECM) molecular precursor solutions, we were able to demonstrate high cell viability, a diversity of cellular functionalities like proliferation and migration, and the formation of ECM networks. This work has made impacts in the 3D bioprinting field and has the potential to influence the fields of tissue engineering, regenerative medicine, as well as those investigating organoids or other 3D tissue models in vitro.

3.  In developing these 3D printing techniques and materials, we made fundamental discoveries about the physics of packed microgel elasticity and yielding. Our discoveries linked the physics and electrostatics of the single polymer chains constituting the microgels to the macroscopic properties of the packed phases. This work created further connections between the 3D printing field and areas within Soft Matter, such as polyelectrolyte physics.

4. We developed a method for making hydrocarbon-based microgels swollen in mineral oil which served as a new support material for 3D printing silicone structures. We were able to print silicone features as small as 30 micrometers, or approximately 1/3 the diameter of a human hair. Moreover, the silicone structures were shown to be extremely strong and tough. This work represented a major advancement in the field of silicone 3D printing.

 

Broader Impacts

In addition to the research mission of this project, I had an educational mission: to diversify the undergraduate population in mechanical and aerospace engineering at my university by infusing soft matter concepts and research into the undergraduate educational experience. Through the many lectures, symposia, popular press and news media, and growing interest in soft matter among my colleagues, we saw a clear rise of interest in non-traditional areas in mechanical engineering along with continual growth of underrepresented populations in STEM fields, most notably women. Soft matter has become a part of the culture and lexicon of my department; our two semester senior design course this year focused on 3D bioprinting using the methods developed in this project and my department has added ?soft matter? as a hiring area in our advertisements for faculty hiring.

The research performed for this project involved collaborations with eight different researchers from the UF school of medicine, including faculty, students and postdocs. The relevance of our 3D bioprinting and 3D culture methods to medical research is thus clear. We currently have several spin-off project started that may have significant impacts on human health. For example, we are currently validating a 3D printed immunotherapy model and creating 3D liver tissue models for drug toxicity screening.

Modified by: Thomas Angelini

Image
  • 3D bioprinted shapes like beams and plates behave in predictable ways. The wavelength of buckling and associated threshold forces are can be predicted from basic mechanical theories. These behaviors enable cell-generated forces to be determined in 3D systems.
    Thomas E. Angelini

    3D bioprinted structural elements
